name: NightSky
description: Nominated as a IGF Seamus McNally Finalist, NightSky is an ambient action-puzzle game that offers a gameplay experience unlike any other—cerebral challenges fill uniquely designed picturesque worlds. The player must maneuver a sphere by using realistic physics to advance; each of these worlds is broken into different areas.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP or newer Processor: Intel Atom or above Memory: 512MB RAM Graphics: 3D graphics card  DirectX®: N/A Hard Drive: 100MB

reviews.review_text: NightSky is a well-crafted little physics puzzler. You maipulate a small sphere through a series of 2D mazes with obstacles and puzzles.   In a single sentence: 'Limbo' meets 'The Ball'.   The visuals are striking. It looks like perpetual sunset, with silohuettes of Edward Gorey-style monsters lurking in the background, which are actually more interesting than the game itself. Good sound, too.  Pretty good game on the cheap if you like environmental puzzlers.

It's a calm and enjoyable little game. It's a bit simple, but that works in its atmosphere. Ten dollars admittedly might be too high of a price, but if you can get it for less, it's not bad to play through, especially if you need to relax. It has a few good puzzling hours in it, and even the more difficult levels aren't game-ruining.

NightSky is a simplistic platformer in which the objective is to move an innocent sphere to the end. The end of what? You will have to decide as there's no narrative but your own motives to drive you there.  The controls are simple, movement based, which change depending on the level. In a lot of the levels you are the sphere and directly move it where you want to go. Some levels mix things up a bit and let you control things around the level, where the sphere relies on gravity to move. In one level you control pinball style flippers and in the next just need to hang tight on a moving cart and not fall off. Its all done in a tasteful and simplistic manner to break up flow a bit and make things a tad more interesting.  The world is wrapped in beautifully gradient colored backgrounds which let your mind fill in the gaps where the levels are taking place. Shaded foregrounds representing the physical world you move around and obstacles in your path are complimented by factory-brown backgrounds or misty-white rain plains and orange-yellow sunsets behind shades of trees. It's a good example of less is more and its works very well. Music wise, the soundtrack feels genuine to what you see on screen. Ambient and experiential tacks help with invoking the right emotions that coincide with each levels color.  The developers included a new game plus mode which involves the same levels with some objects modified to make them more challenging. This works for the most part and provides an extra set of achievements to complete and lengthens the game if you are into that sort of thing. I would recommend NightSky to anyone looking for a simple platformer to wind down and hey, if you get addicted to the gameplay - there is the challenging NewGame+ to complete after you are done. Took me about 10 hours to complete to 100%.

This is a review for 'Hold Right Arrow Key to Win Game' in which you ...hold right (perhaps left occasionally) to win. Thats.. basically it. You may think I am kidding, but thats the actual game. There are speed up and slow down powers, anti gravity powers and some other neat stuff that breaks up the fact you just hold right... but still, 90% of the game is holding right and knowing when to not hold right. There were screens and puzzles I never even had time to figure out because holding right just beat them for me. Sure, there are some 'nice' puzzles and some 'fun' challenges... but ..honestly.. I didn't like those parts. It felt kinda like those terrible moments in Sonic where the fluid of the level design stops and you have to struggle to regain it. Its awkward and you just want it to end so you can get back to holding right.   I beat the game, it was painful to do. I have fond moments of holding right..and I have many many bad memories of this game. I have labled it terrible and buried it in the graveyard of games I wish I didn't own. If considering purchase, please skip over this game. There are plenty of similar games that are much better examples of what you really want.

NightSky is a simple yet engaging physics puzzle platformer using a ball and the various terrain and objects to get through each level. The controls are simple to move the ball which moves quickly, but extra controls are given to move it faster, slower, or upside down depending on the level along with various contraptions and other objects that are required to solve the levels. Each level is crisply and cleanly drawn with black vector objects along with a well textured sky background in nature or non-nature settings. The art style opts for a simple and almost minimal look along with more intricate and articulate designs in other levels. The music and sounds are also ambient to suit the level styles, with natural sounds and small pieces of music to go with each level. Some levels may be really straightforward and easy, while others give a good amount of puzzle thinking or platforming skill to complete. While it looks like just a simplistic game, NightSky gives a good experience with some interesting design and gameplay.

Nightsky is a challenging physics puzzle game where you control a ball with various abilities as you try to navigate across progressively difficult playing fields. The developers have done an exceptional job here, not only with the attractive and stylish visuals, but with the excellent soundtrack as well. My major complaint with the title is that it is presented on a tiny window that cannot be scaled, making the gamefield tiny on a widescreen monitor. However, I found that after playomg for a few minutes I stopped noticing this as the rest of the presentation is so engaging. I would recommend this game to puzzle gamers who are not turned off by a high twitch requirement and are willing to attempt to complete the same puzzle multiple times before getting it right. Overall this is a very well made game and worth the price.
